posts.post_content:
@PhyrexianFailure: *"strictly better than Dross Crocodile. still not exactly good."*  
  
This card isn't "strictly better" than Dross Crocodile. In most cases, it's better, yes, but as an artifact as well as a creature, it's vulnerable to twice the removal that the crocodile is. The Souleater's additional *weakness* compared to the crocodile means it's not "strictly better," which implies no such weaknesses.
posts.html:
@PhyrexianFailure: "strictly better than Dross Crocodile. still not exactly good."

This card isn't "strictly better" than Dross Crocodile. In most cases, it's better, yes, but as an artifact as well as a creature, it's vulnerable to twice the removal that the crocodile is. The Souleater's additional weakness compared to the crocodile means it's not "strictly better," which implies no such weaknesses.

Posted By: steinburger1109 (7/1/2012 9:33:03 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: I think it's actually pretty good. With [Glissa, the Traitor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Glissa, the Traitor) out, you can have something either hitting them in the face for 5 or have a blocker with 5 power (which, if it isn't trampling or a first striker, is quite good for a creature that costs 4), and you can screw around with their heads by activating it's ability at the last moment, meaning if they really don't want to take any damage, they have to throw more creatures at it. With Glissa out, that means you can bring it back each time it kills something. Ok, so it costs 4 to do it each time, but hey, that's basically 4 mana to get a creature with a power of 5 out that only stays dead for so long.
posts.html:
